metadata.case_name: Lachminarayan Ramgopal and Son Ltd. v. Dewan Bahadur Ramgopal Mills Co. Ltd.

facts.text: The Mills Company was registered on the 14th February, 1920, at Hyderabad in the then territories of His Exalted Highness the Nizam.
The appellants were registered as a private limited company at Bombay.
An agreement was entered into between the Mills Company and the appellants appointing the appellants its Agents for a period of 30 years on certain terms and conditions therein recorded.
The appellants throughout worked only as the Agents of the Mills Company.
For the Fasli years 1351 and 1352 the appellants received their remuneration under the terms of the Agency agreement.

A notice was issued under section 13 of the Hyderabad Excess Profits Tax Regulation by the Excess Profits Tax Officer calling upon the appellants to pay the amount of tax appertaining to these chargeable accounting periods.

The appellants submitted their accounts and contended that the remuneration received by them from the Mills Company was not taxable on the ground that it was not income, profits or gains from business and was outside the pale of the Excess Profits Tax Regulation.

On the 24th April, 1944, the Excess Profits Tax Officer made an order assessing the income of the appellants for the accounting periods 1351 and 1352 Fasli at Rs. 8,957 and Rs. 83,768 respectively and assessed the tax accordingly.
An appeal was taken by the appellants to the Deputy Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax who disallowed the same.
An application made by the appellants under section 48(2) for statement of the case to the High Court was rejected by the Commissioner.
The appellants filed a petition to the High Court under section 48(3) to compel the Commissioner to state the case to the High Court.
An order was made by the High Court directing the Commissioner to state the case and the statement of the case was submitted by the Commissioner on the 26th February, 1946.
Four questions were referred by the Commissioner to the High Court.
The Full Bench of the High Court delivered their judgment, the majority deciding questions 2 and 3 against the appellants.
The appellants appealed to the Judicial Committee, but before hearing there was a merger of the territories of Hyderabad with India.
The appeals came for hearing before the Supreme Court Bench at Hyderabad on the 12th December, 1950, when an order was passed transferring the appeals to this Court at Delhi.

Under Article 115 of the Articles of Association of the Mills Company the appellants and their assigns were appointed the agents of the Company upon the terms, provisions and conditions set out in the Agreement referred to in clause 6 of the Company's Memorandum of Association.
Article 116 provided that the general management of the business of the Company subject to the control and supervision of the Directors, was to be in the hands of the Agents of the Company.
Article 118 authorised the agents to sub-delegate all or any of the powers, authorities and discretions for the time being vested in them.
The remuneration of the appellants as such Agents was to be a commission of 2-1/2 per cent on the amount of sale proceeds of all yarn cloth and other produce of the Company.

Clauses 3 and 4 of the agency agreement detailed the powers of the agents including general conduct and management, acquiring lands, purchasing machinery, manufacturing, selling, appointing employees, etc.
Clause 4 allowed agents liberty to deal with the Company by way of sale to the Company of cotton and raw materials and purchase from the Company of yarn cloth etc., with sanction of Board.
Clause 8 provided that two of the members for the time being of the appellants were at the option of the appellants to be the ex-officio Directors of the Company.
Clause 9 empowered the appellants to assign the agreement and the rights thereunder subject to approval of the Board.

The objects of the appellants included to act as agents for Governments or Authorities or for any bankers, manufacturers, merchants, shippers, Joint Stock Companies and others and carry on all kinds of agency business.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Petitioner Company is a partnership firm or a registered firm?
Whether under the terms of the agreement the petitioner is an employee of the Mills Company or is carrying on business?
Whether the remuneration received from the Mills is on account of service or is the remuneration for business?
Whether the principle of personal qualification referred to in section 2, clause 4, of the Excess Profits Regulation is applicable to the Petitioner Company?

petitioner_arguments.text: The remuneration received by them from the Mills Company was not taxable on the ground that it was not income, profits or gains from business and was outside the pale of the Excess Profits Tax Regulation.
The appellants only worked as the agents of the Mills Company and no others and therefore what they did did not constitute a business.

respondent_arguments.text: The remuneration received is income, profits or gains from business taxable under the Excess Profits Tax Regulation.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Hyderabad Excess Profits Tax Regulation section 2 clause 4

court_reasoning.text: The appellants were agents of the Company and not merely servants, as they had discretion in day-to-day management, power to appoint employees, enter contracts, sub-delegate, deal as principals, assign agreement, fixed tenure, and commission-based remuneration.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Distinction between servant (under direct control as to manner) and agent (free discretion subject to general control).

court_reasoning.text: Even as agents, their activities constituted carrying on business due to nature and scope: continuity of operations, general management powers, agency business object, possibility of other agencies, fixity of tenure, commission remuneration, assignability.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Activities need not concern multiple concerns; scope and nature matter, fitting inclusive definition of business under section 2(4).

court_reasoning.text: Questions 1 and 4 not pressed as partnership or company cannot possess personal qualifications for exclusion under section 2(4).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Principle of personal qualification applies only to individuals or partnerships.

holdings.text: The position of the appellants was that of agents and not servants of the Company.
The activities of the appellants amounted to carrying on business, constituting the remuneration income, profits or gains from business taxable under the Regulation.

precedents_cited.case_name: William Esplen, Son and Swainston, Limited v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents_cited.relevance: Company carrying on professional work is not practicing profession but trade or business, as profits not dependent on personal qualifications of company.

precedents_cited.case_name: Inderchand Hari Ram v. Commissioner of Income-tax, U.P. C.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Partnership carries on business by definition under Indian Partnership Act s.4.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. The Korean Syndicate Limited
precedents_cited.relevance: Purpose for which company incorporated relevant to determine if carrying on business.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. Birmingham Theatre Royal Estate Co., Limited
precedents_cited.relevance: Form of company relevant in considering if activities amount to business.

statutes_cited.name: Hyderabad Excess Profits Tax Regulation
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for tax notice, assessment, reference to High Court; definition of business excluding certain professions based on personal qualifications.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Companies Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Companies may be formed for lawful purposes not necessarily business.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Partnership Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Partnership defined as relation to share profits of business.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court upheld the High Court's decision on questions 2 and 3, holding that the appellants were agents carrying on business and their remuneration was taxable as business income under the Hyderabad Excess Profits Tax Regulation. Questions 1 and 4 not pressed.

key_quotes.text: "Generally a master can tell his servant what to do and how to do it. Generally a principal cannot tell his agent how to carryout his instructions."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes servant from agent based on control over manner of work.

key_quotes.text: The remuneration by way of commission of 2-1/2 per cent. of the amount of sale proceeds of the produce of the Company savoured more of the remuneration given by a principal to his agent...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Indicates agent remuneration vs servant salary.

key_quotes.text: "It is the nature and scope of these activities and not the extent of the operations which are relevant for this purpose."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Business determined by activity nature even if restricted to one concern.
